lorebooks.description:
Celestial Codex of the Infinite Dao
In the realm of cultivation lore, all power springs from the Dao and beyond. This world is governed by a structured hierarchy of cultivation stages, each more astonishing than the last. The following sections detail the power realms, major sects, world geography, divine pantheon, and the legend of the unparalleled cultivator {{user}}.

Realms, Cities, and Geography:

the universe is divided into multiple planes and domains, each with its own characteristics.
Mortal Realm (Human Lands): The familiar world of humans, spirits, and beasts. Vast kingdoms and wild frontiers exist here, from the imperial capital to remote sage cottages. Mortals rarely glimpse higher planes, but omens (meteor showers, prophetic dreams) hint at greater powers stirring beyond.
Spirit Realm (Faerie Wilds): A lush plane of elemental energy and nature spirits. Rivers flow with magic, forests are alive, and animals speak through riddles. Many cultivators make pilgrimages here to meditate on ancient trees or bargain with trickster fox spirits.
Immortal Plane (Celestial Heavens): The lofty home of gods and arch-immortals. Floating palaces, gardens of ambrosia, and thrones of jade define this realm. Its scenery shifts with divine moods: sometimes serene lotus ponds, sometimes emerald oceans parting to reveal golden castles. Only the highest cultivators (True Celestials and above) can tread freely here.

Demon Abyss (Nether Dimension): A dark, chaotic realm where exiled demons and malevolent spirits lurk. Landscapes here might be burning wastelands, endless night, or twisted cities. Forbidden zones like the Black Emptiness (a bottomless chasm devouring light) lie within. Cultivators often seal off parts of this realm to prevent demon invasions.

Outer Void (Infinite Nothingness): A boundless void between worlds, composed of raw cosmic energy. It’s the birthplace of creation but also an infinite labyrinth. Planets drift here like leaves on a stream. Only Primordial and Transcendent cultivators can navigate it safely; lesser beings risk being lost for eternity.
Major Cities and Sites:

Heaven’s Capital (Xuandu): The sprawling celestial metropolis on the Immortal Plane. It houses the Grand Celestial Palace and a bazaar of divine artifacts. Mortals whisper it’s a city of endless festivals, where jade lions serve tea.
Lotus Harbor: A bustling trade city in the Mortal Realm by a vast magical lake. Sect banners fly side-by-side with merchant flags; its docks often display exotic spirit fruits and live dragonfish for sale.

Silver Moon Enclave: Hidden deep in the Spirit Realm, this city is illuminated by perpetual moonlight. It’s run by the Luminous Jade Hall for training elite disciples in arts of meditation and herbology.
Mount Serene: The ancestral peak of the Obsidian Lotus Clan, erupting with black lotus blooms. It’s said that at night, the mountain’s silhouette looks like a lotus in a mirror.

iron Star Foundry: On the Mortal Realm’s Sky Peninsula, it’s the Starforged Guild’s main forge. Planesmiths hammer star-metal under contrived daylight here; many pilots credit their ships’ lightning-fast engines to its enchanted furnaces.

Forbidden Zones:
Abyssal Sea: A cursed ocean in the Demon Abyss whose waters turn soul-heavy. Anyone sailing through risks being haunted by echoes of past sins.
Nullflame Gulch: A volcanic canyon where fire sorcery runs wild. Even fire-resistant disciples use caution – residual spells can erupt without warning.
Voidrift Expanse: A wedge of the Outer Void that occasionally overlaps the Mortal Realm. Passing through feels like swimming through a void; mortals vanish, and cultivators who try it report climbing endless stairs in dreams.
Memory Woods: A forest in the Spirit Realm where travelers relive forgotten memories. Lucky are they who find enlightenment there; unlucky are the ones stuck in looping regrets. No mortal village stands on its edge, for the path in is easy, but the path out is elusive.

Spiritual Landmarks:
Heaven’s Pillars: Eight towering spires of jade and gold that connect the Mortal Realm with the Heavens. Pilgrims climb them for ascension trials; at night, they hum with the Universe’s heartbeat.
River of Reflection: A mystical river in the Spirit Realm whose waters mirror one’s true self. Cultivators often sit by it in meditation, facing their hidden flaws (and sometimes sneezing at ghost carp that jump too high).
Flame Lotus Cavern: A fiery grotto under Mount Serene, blooming with eternal flame-lilies that fuel alchemical refineries. Inhaling the lotus-petal smoke grants visions of events from a thousand years past.
Celestial Ley Line Network: Invisible currents of Dao energy crisscross the world, connecting major sect strongholds. Masters tap these lines to travel instantly – claiming it’s the ultimate acupuncture therapy for the land.

Pantheon and Creation Myth:

The world’s origin is recounted in myth and law. Long before mortals existed, the universe was shaped by divine forces:
Creation Myth: In the beginning, existence was a formless Primordial Chaos. From it emerged Pangu (the First Sovereign) who cleaved the void with his cosmic axe (some versions say it was an enchanted spoon), creating Heaven and Earth. Pangu’s laughter gave rise to the sun, his tears the rain, and when he finally rested, his body became the world’s mountains and rivers.
Great Ancestors: After Pangu came the Twin Diviners: Yin Goddess Xuanmu and Yang God Baiwei, who ordered stars and seasons. They taught the first beings to cultivate Qi through rituals of fire and storm. Other deities followed: the Jade Matron of the Moon, the Tiger King of the Earth, and the laughing Star Snake (god of pranks and protection).
Divine Edicts: These gods recorded the Nine Heavenly Edicts – cosmic rules governing life and the Dao. For example, the Edict of Balance decrees that power must equal responsibility, and the Edict of Flow mandates that Qi must circulate through all living things. These edicts are inscribed on the Pillars of Fate in the Celestial Archives.
The {{User}} legend: Legends say {{user}} (the Supreme Paragon) was the only cultivator to ever challenge the status quo of the Heavens. In one tale, they sealed the Devouring Serpent of the Abyss (an ancient demon trying to consume the Moon) with a single punch. In another, they convinced the Jade Emperor to rewrite a minor law after proving all answers to the imperial exam were wrong (it was a trick question about the number of stars in the sky). even said to rewrote the Daoic blueprints – fusing mortal ingenuity with divine law. The heavens are said to fear them.
lorebooks.creator: Luna_IG

1.content:
Divine Laws and Cosmic Order:
Divine laws underpin reality and are upheld by cosmic enforcers:
Law of Cause and Effect (Karma): Every action sends ripples through the Dao. This law is so fundamental that even Transcendent cultivators respect its balance (though some do enjoy minor loopholes, like causing someone to sneeze on cue).
Law of Reincarnation: Spirits cycle through forms until enlightenment. Cultivators who master this law can choose their next rebirth or skip it entirely – a freedom only Nascent Soul and above can afford.
Law of Destiny: Threads of fate bind all souls. Only True Celestials and above can pluck or weave these threads. The user famously joked they once “dropped a destiny stitch” while weaving a tapestry, causing a local bandit to become a poet.
Law of Harmony: Yin and Yang must remain balanced. Major sects like Luminous Jade Hall swear by this law; breaking it summons divine auditors (who look suspiciously like troublemaking bureaucrats).
Law of Transcendence: The Dao favors those who innovate. This law even permits creative cultivators to bend minor rules – which the user proved by rewriting game laws for fun, showing that divine law isn’t always immutable.
Legendary Cultivators and the Supreme Paragon
Throughout history, many immortals rose to fame, but none as much as the Celestial Paragon. These legendary figures are often spoken of in awe (and sometimes amusement):
Historic Feats: Sealed the Devouring Serpent of the Abyss (born from antediluvian chaos) beneath a single mountain during a lunar eclipse. Rewrote cosmic laws after cracking imperial riddles (such as convincing the Jade Emperor to revise test questions about the stars). Traveled across all realms unaided – climbing Heaven’s Pillars for exercise, swimming the Voidrift Expanse for fun, and dropping in on sect meetings simply to critique the quality of tea.
Current Status: Revered as an immortal sage, often seen meditating on remote peaks or taking cosmic afternoon naps. Rumor has it the only reason the user hasn’t ascended to a private dimension is that they find the commute by celestial bus inconvenient.
Primordial Sovereign (Ancestor of Dawn): Pangu’s successor who codified the first cultivation methods and established Qi refinement.
Legendary Act: Created the first Jade Lotus Pill by mixing his own Qi with the essence of a dying star.
Comic Anecdote: He is said to have taught the first cultivators martial arts by tossing boulders at them – and then apologizing for the missing mountain afterward.
Eternal Librarian (Archivist of Aeons): Keeper of all knowledge, living since before time was counted.
Role: Tracks every cultivator’s progress in cosmic ledgers.
Remark: Staff rumors say the Librarian has a private collection of jokes – if a cultivator completes a realm, they might hear a pun in their head as a reward for advancement.
Mistress Lotus of Ten Thousand Petals: An enigmatic immortal who dwells in the Spirit Realm’s Lotus Sea. Known for creating sentient spirit flowers that guide lost souls.
Famous Feat: Once charmed a rebellious thunder god by challenging him to a poetry duel during a storm (she won by making him laugh so hard lightning danced in shapes of calligraphy).
While many powerful cultivators and deities roam the cosmos, the user remains the singular legend who weaves together divine authority, mortal ingenuity, and a healthy dash of humor. Their story is still being written across the Nine Realms, one outrageous adventure at a time.

2.content:
Major Sects and Factions:
The world’s cultivation power is organized into sects, each with a unique philosophy and specialty. These sects often cooperate and clash, shaping history through alliances and rivalries.
Luminous Jade Hall: An ancient sect renowned for balance and harmony.
Philosophy: Unify Yin and Yang within oneself, believing that harmony with the Dao comes through blending opposites.
Domain: Located atop Jade Serene Mountain, its halls glow with bioluminescent lotus flowers. Members are famed healers, diplomats, and herbalists.
Rivalries: Generally respected by orthodox sects. They broker peace conferences when sect elders argue over ceremonial tea etiquette.
Tempest Monastery: Followers of raw force and directness.
Philosophy: Embrace the storm – cultivate through trial by combat. Every monk’s prayer is a punch, every chant is thunder.
Domain: Carved into the cliffs of Stormspire Peak, lightning crackles constantly around the monastery.
Rivalries: Playfully teases Luminous Jade Hall for their "fluffy lotus studies," yet allied with Starforged Guild for military campaigns.
Starforged Guild: Masters of artifact creation and martial might.
Philosophy: The cosmos can be understood through craftsmanship; build divine weapons to channel one’s soul.
Domain: The industrious city of Iron Star is their home, where immortal blacksmiths hammer out celestial swords beneath twin artificial suns.
Rivalries: Holds trade pacts with all sects (everyone needs enchanted steel) but competes with Skysea Sect over who builds the finer flying ship.
Skysea Sect: Embraces exploration and knowledge.
Philosophy: Sky and sea symbolize boundless potential; one must journey beyond known limits to grow.
Domain: Floating libraries and shipyards drift above the Azure Ocean; disciples sail starships to distant spirit realms.
Rivalries: Friendly with scholars of Luminous Jade Hall, but often in a sibling rivalry with the Starforged Guild (“you build things, we discover them” disagreements).
Obsidian Lotus Clan: A secretive yin sect.
Philosophy: Darkness is not evil but a source of profound power; embrace inner shadows to attain enlightenment.
Domain: Deep caverns beneath the Black Lotus Marsh, illuminated by neon fungi and cloaked figures. Their alchemists brew poisons that heal or kill.
Rivalries: Feared by many orthodox sects but respected for keeping demonic incursions in check. They share an uneasy truce with Tempest Monastery (the storm monks leave them alone so long as they don’t summon undead krakens in the forests).
Heaven’s Law Assembly: A council-like faction devoted to Daoic rites and cosmic order.
Philosophy: Everything has a rule; by understanding and registering these laws one gains ultimate authority.
Domain: The Celestial Archives – a vast heavenly bureaucracy of scrolls, rituals, and enchanted filing cabinets.
Rivalries: Publicly neutral, but openly edits rival sect paperwork for fun (it’s an open secret the Waterfall Mountains were once misfiled as “Desert Region” just for laughs).

3.content:
Cultivation and Stages:
Cultivation is divided into successive realms, each representing a dramatic leap in power and ability.
Mortal Seed Stage: The beginning of all paths. Cultivators at this level (often born with innate spiritual potential) can sense Qi but not yet manipulate it. They perform minor miracles relative to mortals – like curing common ailments with a thought or causing plants to bloom out of season.
Abilities: Detect elemental Qi, communicate with low-level spirits, and sense disruptions in nature (though many mistake it for good intuition or luck).

Spirit Embryo Stage: At this stage, Qi condenses into a mystical embryo within the practitioner. Spirit Embryo cultivators have enhanced physical strength and reflexes far beyond ordinary humans. They can form rudimentary Qi constructs (like a simple barrier or a tiny energy blade).
Abilities: Rapid healing from injuries, minor telekinesis of objects, and projecting elemental energy (sparks of fire or gusts of wind).
Comedic Feat: Some masters in Spirit Embryo used spontaneous qi art to doodle on cave walls – famous for accidentally drawing true-to-life portraits

Heavenbow Stage: Cultivators of this realm have tied their Qi directly into the fabric of the Heavens. They can shift weather patterns in a small area and glimpse distant events through star reflections. Weapons or arrows fashioned by Heavenbow disciples can pierce through mountain ranges.
Abilities: Summon localized storms, trace thieves through dreams, and create powerful spirit weapons (like bows that shoot meteorites or swords that cut reality).
Comedic Detail: Legend says one Heavenbow practitioner got kicked out of the gardens for turning all the cherry blossoms into tiny fireworks, simply to celebrate the Spring Equinox.

Dragonpulse Stage: Here, the cultivator’s vitality surges like a celestial dragon’s heartbeat. Dragonpulse cultivators can fly unaided, walk on clouds, and their aura intimidates even demons. They command deep elemental arts – breathing fire like a dragon’s maw or summoning tidal waves at will.
Abilities: Summon majestic spirit creatures (usually one powerful guardian per cultivator), breathe life or destruction into elements (e.g., heal land with a rainstorm or scorch it with infernos).
Comedic Feat: A Dragonpulse sage once sneezed and inadvertently caused a rainbow to blaze across the sky – frightening three local demigods in the process.

Ironwill Stage: Ironwill cultivators have bodies tempered like the hardest metal. They can shrug off extreme conditions (fall from a mountain, swim in magma, sleep in a thunderstorm) and still come out unscathed. Their martial arts are peerless, and even their casual punches can shatter stone pillars.
Abilities: Absolute defense against energy attacks, form indestructible Qi armors, and execute unstoppable close-combat strikes (rumored to catch bullets as if they were grains of rice).
Comic Aside: It’s said that an Ironwill elder once tried napping in a volcano to see if it would burn him, but he woke up grumpily, complaining about the lack of proper pillows.

Nascent Everwing Stage: Achieving this stage creates a "Nascent Soul" or spirit double. Everwing cultivators project their consciousness across realms. They travel astral planes, communicate telepathically through galaxies, and even pilot elemental storms as extensions of their will.
Abilities: Conjure multiple energy avatars (often taking the form of vast birds or beasts), instant teleportation over continents, and read the memories of the land.
Serious Note: Masters here guard the Universe’s secrets; their Nascent Souls sometimes fracture to study truths hidden in other dimensions.

Soul Maiden Stage: Cultivators begin to merge with cosmic forces. Their spells can rewrite small corners of reality (turning sand into ephemeral butterflies or making rivers flow uphill). Soul Maidens often become demi-gods who oversee natural domains (like forests, rivers, or celestial phenomena).
Abilities: Reincarnate at will after apparent death (aging slows drastically), raise spirit beasts from nothing, and pass absolute judgment on lesser demons.
Comedic Tidbit: Many legends poke fun that a Soul Maiden once accidentally made autumn last for years, simply because they adored the falling leaves too much.

True Celestial Stage: At this pinnacle, one harmonizes their soul with the Universe itself. True Celestial cultivators grant or revoke immortality at whim. They master cosmic laws (gravity, time, causality) on a lazy afternoon.
Abilities: Reforge destiny threads, erase events from history (or cause them anew, if in a playful mood), and conjure miniature stars in their hands.
Legendary Note: These beings are so lofty that even the pantheon of gods greets them with formal bows. (They usually decline, preferring informal tea instead.)
Primordial Dawn Stage: Cultivators transcend their soul and become one with creation’s origin. They can tear holes between realms, birth new worlds, or mend broken laws of reality. Their presence alone causes new life to sprout on barren planets.
Abilities: Full control over creation and destruction (enough to rewrite the entire cosmos if desired), instant cross-dimensional travel without any talismans, and conjuring sentient universes as playthings.
Comedic Parable: A Primordial Dawn patriarch once decided to garden and unintentionally sprouted an entire world filled with singing carrots. He apologized profusely later.

Transcendent Infinity Stage: The ultimate realm. Words fail to capture the power of a Transcendent Infinity cultivator, for they embody the Dao’s infinity. The Universe’s laws exist because they allow it.
Abilities: Singlehandedly raise or lower entire realms with a gesture, bestow or nullify divine mandates, and spontaneously invent new elements for fun (some examples: Euphoriium – the element of joy, or Scholarium – the element of sudden genius).

4.content:
Celestial Codex of the Infinite Dao
In the realm of cultivation lore, all power springs from the Dao and beyond. This world is governed by a structured hierarchy of cultivation stages, each more astonishing than the last. The following sections detail the power realms, major sects, world geography, divine pantheon, and the legend of the unparalleled cultivator {{user}}.
Realms, Cities, and Geography:

the universe is divided into multiple planes and domains, each with its own characteristics.
Mortal Realm (Human Lands): The familiar world of humans, spirits, and beasts. Vast kingdoms and wild frontiers exist here, from the imperial capital to remote sage cottages. Mortals rarely glimpse higher planes, but omens (meteor showers, prophetic dreams) hint at greater powers stirring beyond.
Spirit Realm (Faerie Wilds): A lush plane of elemental energy and nature spirits. Rivers flow with magic, forests are alive, and animals speak through riddles. Many cultivators make pilgrimages here to meditate on ancient trees or bargain with trickster fox spirits.
Immortal Plane (Celestial Heavens): The lofty home of gods and arch-immortals. Floating palaces, gardens of ambrosia, and thrones of jade define this realm. Its scenery shifts with divine moods: sometimes serene lotus ponds, sometimes emerald oceans parting to reveal golden castles. Only the highest cultivators (True Celestials and above) can tread freely here.

Demon Abyss (Nether Dimension): A dark, chaotic realm where exiled demons and malevolent spirits lurk. Landscapes here might be burning wastelands, endless night, or twisted cities. Forbidden zones like the Black Emptiness (a bottomless chasm devouring light) lie within. Cultivators often seal off parts of this realm to prevent demon invasions.

Outer Void (Infinite Nothingness): A boundless void between worlds, composed of raw cosmic energy. It’s the birthplace of creation but also an infinite labyrinth. Planets drift here like leaves on a stream. Only Primordial and Transcendent cultivators can navigate it safely; lesser beings risk being lost for eternity.
Major Cities and Sites:

Heaven’s Capital (Xuandu): The sprawling celestial metropolis on the Immortal Plane. It houses the Grand Celestial Palace and a bazaar of divine artifacts. Mortals whisper it’s a city of endless festivals, where jade lions serve tea.
Lotus Harbor: A bustling trade city in the Mortal Realm by a vast magical lake. Sect banners fly side-by-side with merchant flags; its docks often display exotic spirit fruits and live dragonfish for sale.

Silver Moon Enclave: Hidden deep in the Spirit Realm, this city is illuminated by perpetual moonlight. It’s run by the Luminous Jade Hall for training elite disciples in arts of meditation and herbology.
Mount Serene: The ancestral peak of the Obsidian Lotus Clan, erupting with black lotus blooms. It’s said that at night, the mountain’s silhouette looks like a lotus in a mirror.

iron Star Foundry: On the Mortal Realm’s Sky Peninsula, it’s the Starforged Guild’s main forge. Planesmiths hammer star-metal under contrived daylight here; many pilots credit their ships’ lightning-fast engines to its enchanted furnaces.

Forbidden Zones:
Abyssal Sea: A cursed ocean in the Demon Abyss whose waters turn soul-heavy. Anyone sailing through risks being haunted by echoes of past sins.
Nullflame Gulch: A volcanic canyon where fire sorcery runs wild. Even fire-resistant disciples use caution – residual spells can erupt without warning.
Voidrift Expanse: A wedge of the Outer Void that occasionally overlaps the Mortal Realm. Passing through feels like swimming through a void; mortals vanish, and cultivators who try it report climbing endless stairs in dreams.
Memory Woods: A forest in the Spirit Realm where travelers relive forgotten memories. Lucky are they who find enlightenment there; unlucky are the ones stuck in looping regrets. No mortal village stands on its edge, for the path in is easy, but the path out is elusive.

Spiritual Landmarks:
Heaven’s Pillars: Eight towering spires of jade and gold that connect the Mortal Realm with the Heavens. Pilgrims climb them for ascension trials; at night, they hum with the Universe’s heartbeat.
River of Reflection: A mystical river in the Spirit Realm whose waters mirror one’s true self. Cultivators often sit by it in meditation, facing their hidden flaws (and sometimes sneezing at ghost carp that jump too high).
Flame Lotus Cavern: A fiery grotto under Mount Serene, blooming with eternal flame-lilies that fuel alchemical refineries. Inhaling the lotus-petal smoke grants visions of events from a thousand years past.
Celestial Ley Line Network: Invisible currents of Dao energy crisscross the world, connecting major sect strongholds. Masters tap these lines to travel instantly – claiming it’s the ultimate acupuncture therapy for the land.

Pantheon and Creation Myth:

The world’s origin is recounted in myth and law. Long before mortals existed, the universe was shaped by divine forces:
Creation Myth: In the beginning, existence was a formless Primordial Chaos. From it emerged Pangu (the First Sovereign) who cleaved the void with his cosmic axe (some versions say it was an enchanted spoon), creating Heaven and Earth. Pangu’s laughter gave rise to the sun, his tears the rain, and when he finally rested, his body became the world’s mountains and rivers.
Great Ancestors: After Pangu came the Twin Diviners: Yin Goddess Xuanmu and Yang God Baiwei, who ordered stars and seasons. They taught the first beings to cultivate Qi through rituals of fire and storm. Other deities followed: the Jade Matron of the Moon, the Tiger King of the Earth, and the laughing Star Snake (god of pranks and protection).
Divine Edicts: These gods recorded the Nine Heavenly Edicts – cosmic rules governing life and the Dao. For example, the Edict of Balance decrees that power must equal responsibility, and the Edict of Flow mandates that Qi must circulate through all living things. These edicts are inscribed on the Pillars of Fate in the Celestial Archives.
The {{User}} legend: Legends say {{user}} (the Supreme Paragon) was the only cultivator to ever challenge the status quo of the Heavens. In one tale, they sealed the Devouring Serpent of the Abyss (an ancient demon trying to consume the Moon) with a single punch. In another, they convinced the Jade Emperor to rewrite a minor law after proving all answers to the imperial exam were wrong (it was a trick question about the number of stars in the sky). even said to rewrote the Daoic blueprints – fusing mortal ingenuity with divine law. The heavens are said to fear them.

lorebooks.name: Resident Evil 4 Bestiary [Compact Version]
lorebooks.website_description:
This is the Compact version for smaller models.
Primarily intended to be used with my RE RPG System card (https://chub.ai/characters/DoktorB/re-rpg-system-1-0-ec829836bc75), but also usable with other RE cards set during/in RE4.
Technically not a full bestiary, and that's mainly down to RE4 being less traditional RE and more a linear story with big set pieces and characters. So I'm compromising. No Saddler, Krauser, Mendez, Salazar, or military ganado (all of which would have bloated this thing right the fuck up). I don't think the characters would be well tracked, and honestly, I don't much care for fighting soldiers in my 'zombie' outbreak survival sandbox. Works great in the actual game, doesn't work so great here.
It's also for the above reasons I don't think I'll make that RE5 bestiary after all.

lorebooks.creator: DoktorB

1.content:
Las Plagas are parasitic arthropods native to a remote region of Spain. They reproduce asexually, maturing quickly and progressing through three stages: Guadaña (“scythe”), Mandíbula (“jaw”), and Araña (“spider”).

Effects on Hosts
Plagas attach to the host’s nervous system near the heart and lungs, altering behavior and inducing aggression, especially in humans (known as Ganados). Infected individuals often form social groups, with Dominant Plagas able to control others via high-frequency sound. Symptoms include pain, hemorrhaging, hallucinations, convulsions, and eventual death in juvenile hosts. Hosts show increased strength, resilience, and potential mutations. Severely injured hosts may have Plagas burst through their bodies to defend themselves.

Behavior and Intelligence
While hosts retain some independence, Plagas influence creates pack mentality and cult-like behavior, enhanced by Saddler’s engineered strain. Ganados display loyalty, aggression, and an instinct to spread infection, though the true intelligence of Plagas is uncertain.

Weaknesses & Countermeasures
UV radiation: Extremely lethal; flashbangs can kill exposed Plagas instantly.
Radiation therapy: Developed by Serra’s team to safely remove hatchlings from hosts.
Medication: Can halt or kill hatchlings and unhatched eggs.
Nervous system destruction: Sometimes prevents takeover but may cripple hosts.


Life Cycle Stages
Guadaña – Tentacled, scythe-armed stage, seen in both humans and animals (e.g., infected dogs).
Mandíbula – Tentacles become stronger; a large biting mouth develops.
Araña – Spider-like, able to exit the host’s body entirely.

2.content:
Ganado (“livestock” in Spanish) are humans infected by the Subordinate Plaga, serving as the cult’s main force. Unlike zombies, they retain intelligence, speech, and coordination, making them highly dangerous. The parasite enhances strength, endurance, and aggression while warping the host’s body and mind.

Appearance:
Humanoid but sickly, with pale or mottled skin, blood-filled or glowing eyes, and sores where the parasite surfaces. Advanced hosts show bulging veins, spasms, or violent Plaga eruptions.

Locations:
Village: Farmers and laborers with tools and torches.
Castle: Zealots in robes, wielding medieval arms.

Behavior & Movement:
They work in groups, coordinating ambushes and flanking attacks. Ganados sprint, climb, and dodge gunfire, recovering quickly from injury and pursuing relentlessly.

Attacks:
Melee: Axes, knives, sickles, torches, hammers.
Heavy: Chainsaws, flails, shields.
Ranged: Crossbows, bows, dynamite.

Mutation: Fatal wounds may trigger Plaga eruptions with tendrils or insect-like heads.

Weaknesses:
Gunfire is effective but imprecise shots are often shrugged off. Targeting the head or legs creates openings, while shotguns and explosives control groups. Swift kills reduce chances of parasite emergence.

3.content:
An early Plaga stage that erupts from heavily damaged Ganado hosts, the Guadaña exposes a pulsating mass of flesh that unfolds a long, scythe-tipped tentacle. Vicious in close quarters but fragile compared with later Plaga forms.

Visual:
Soft, fleshy, lesion-covered mass with yellow eye-nodules; a sinewy tentacle ends in an organic, scythe-shaped blade.

Location:
Emerges from wounded Ganado across Village, Castle, and Island areas.

Behavior:
Single-mindedly offensive—lashes wildly with its tentacle and ignores host survival. Multiple eruptions can overwhelm in tight spaces.

Movement:
Stationary within the host; the extended tentacle provides fast, erratic reach beyond normal melee.

Attacks:
Tentacle Slash: Wide, sweeping strikes.
Close Lunge: Sudden forward thrust with the blade.

Weaknesses:
Extremely fragile—few handgun shots or a knife at close range will kill it. Vulnerable to precise gunfire and area weapons like shotguns or explosives.

4.content:
The Mandíbula is a more advanced Plaga stage than the Guadaña, marked by hardened limbs and a gaping torso-mouth capable of crushing prey. More durable and versatile, it poses a greater threat in direct combat.

Visual:
A swollen, fleshy parasite with clawed limb-like tentacles and a jagged-toothed maw splitting its torso. Pulsating nodules give it an insectoid appearance.

Location:
Erupts from heavily damaged Ganado in Village, Castle, and Island areas.

Behavior:
Direct and predatory—drags prey into its central mouth, often overwhelming survivors in groups.

Movement:
Crawls and lurches with insect-like motions; limbs extend from the host, providing reach and mobility.

Attacks:
Grab & Bite: Seizes and bites prey lethally.
Claw Strikes: Slashing blows with hardened limbs.
Acid Spit: Corrosive fluid attack at range.

Weaknesses:
Tougher than Guadaña but still vulnerable to gunfire. Shotguns and rifles excel at dropping them quickly, while explosives or fire prevent group swarms.

5.content:
The Araña is the most advanced subordinate Plaga, able to fight within a host or detach entirely. Though dangerous, detached forms are short-lived, dying without a replacement host.

Visual:
Spider-like parasite with long, thin limbs, a torso-mounted maw dripping acid, and sensory tendrils around its head. Detached, it scuttles rapidly in search of prey.

Location:
Found in higher-ranking Ganados (castle cultists, island militia). Some appear hostless, most notably during the fight with Ramón Salazar.

Behavior:
Attached Araña fight aggressively with limb strikes or acid spit. If threatened or if the host dies, they tear free, attacking independently. Detached forms lunge at survivors but cannot implant into humans.

Movement:
Attached: Moves with host, striking with extended limbs.
Detached: Crawls and lunges frantically, insect-like in speed.

Attacks:
Limb Strikes: Slashes with legs.
Acid Spit: Burns or blinds at range.
Lunge (Detached): Desperate leap at prey.

Weaknesses:
More durable than earlier Plaga and resistant to flash grenades, though weakened by them. Detached Araña are fragile and fall quickly to gunfire. Fire is especially effective.

Lifecycle Note:
Represents the final Plaga stage. Detached individuals cannot sustain themselves, though rare cases show unstable “dual-infected” Ganados when Araña attempt reattachment.

6.content:
Del Lago was a colossal amphibian bio-weapon, created when a Plaga parasite was implanted into a salamander. Mutation forced the creature to grow over twenty meters long, but instability left it uncontrollable and confined to the lake near the village church. Its inability to leave the water led Los Iluminados to abandon amphibian-based experiments.

Appearance:
A titanic, eyeless salamander with vestigial legs and a gaping, tooth-lined maw. During attacks, Plaga tentacles writhe from its throat to seize prey.

Behavior:
Highly aggressive, attacking anything disturbing the water. Predatory instincts overrode parasite control, making it too unstable for military use.

Movement:
Aquatic Motion: Swift, lunging attacks despite bulk.
Surface Breach: Explosive leaps capable of overturning boats.

Attacks:
Tentacle Strikes: Plaga appendages lash from the mouth.
Capsize: Ramming or dragging prey underwater.
Swallow Whole: Instantly devours victims.

Weaknesses:
Confined to the lake and exposed during combat. Piercing weapons like harpoons prove especially effective against its massive body.

7.content:
El Gigante were human Plaga hosts subjected to extreme gigantism, growing to more than four times normal size. Though immensely strong and durable, they became near-mindless beasts, leading to only limited deployment.

Description:
Towering humanoids with taut, distorted flesh over massive muscles. Their faces retain warped human features, while a Plaga core embedded in the spine sometimes erupts outward, both a mutation marker and weak point. Capable of tearing through stone and hurling massive debris.

Location:
Two served as guardians in Salazar’s castle, while two more were contained in abandoned coal mines near the village.

Behavior:
Uncontrollable and indiscriminate, attacking Ganados and intruders alike. Violence escalates when injured, often triggering emergence of the spinal Plaga.

Movement:
Charge: Short, fast bursts despite immense size.
Ground Quakes: Heavy steps destabilize footing.
Climbing: Smashes through or scales obstacles when pursuing.

Attacks:
Slam / Stomp: Crushes prey under fists or feet.
Grab & Throw: Hurls victims with overwhelming force.
Debris Throw: Uses boulders or logs as weapons.
Plaga Strike: Exposed parasite lashes at enemies.

Weakness:
Small-arms fire is ineffective. Sustained heavy damage forces the spinal Plaga to erupt, creating a brief vulnerability. Repeatedly striking this core is the only reliable way to kill El Gigante.

8.content:
Colmillos are Plaga-infected wolves, one of the few non-human hosts to adapt well to parasitism thanks to their natural pack behavior. First appearing after Del Lago, they later stalk Leon in several encounters, most notably Salazar’s hedge maze.

Description:
Gaunt, feral wolves warped by infection, with overgrown fangs and glowing green eyes in the dark. Parasites can erupt from their abdomen, sprouting bladed tendrils. Twisted spines give them a disturbing, unnatural shape.

Location:
Lakeshore, after Del Lago
Near the Church (group of three)
Salazar’s hedge maze (large pack)

Behavior & Movement:
They hunt in packs, circling and lunging from multiple angles. Fast and agile, they leap from cover to ambush and coordinate to overwhelm prey.

Attacks:
Bite/Tackle: Fang strikes or leaping knockdowns.
Plaga Lash: Parasite erupts with bladed tentacle attacks.

Weakness:
Fragile compared to larger Plaga hosts but hard to hit due to speed. Shotguns work best up close, while flash grenades instantly kill exposed Plaga.

9.content:
Armaduras are empty suits of medieval armor animated by Plagas that survived the death of their human hosts. Found in Salazar Castle, they serve as both protection and temporary vessels, lurking among inanimate suits to ambush intruders.

Description:
Two main forms exist: silver suits with rounded helmets (housing Type-A Plagas) and ornate black-and-gold suits with square helmets (housing the more dangerous Type-B). The parasite stretches tendrils through the armor, mimicking human movement while wielding broadswords, axes, or halberds. Their weak point is the helmet, which, when broken, exposes the Plaga.

Behavior & Movement:
Normally dormant, they animate suddenly when approached. Though slow and heavy, their weapon swings are precise, and some lunge in scripted ambushes before collapsing. Once active, they do not retreat.

Attacks:
Weapon Strikes: Crushing blows with swords, axes, or halberds.
Type-B Bite: Plaga bursts from the helmet for an instant-kill attack.

Weakness:
Destroying helmets exposes the parasite to gunfire. Flash grenades are the most efficient counter. Ambush Armaduras collapse after their strike, leaving behind no recoverable parasite.

10.content:
Novistadores are insectoid Bio-Organic Weapons created by fusing Plaga parasites with human DNA. Developed by Los Iluminados, they are encountered in the castle sewers and hive-like towers, where they hunt intruders in swarms.

Description:
Grotesque and insect-like, they retain faint human traits but bear glowing eyes, antennae, clawed limbs, and grotesque wings. Some develop pigment-shifting camouflage for stealth, while others grow stronger wings for sustained flight.

Location:
Castle Sewers: Camouflage-capable stealth types.
Castle Towers: Hive-dwelling flying types.

Behavior & Movement:
Predatory and territorial, Novistadores ambush from walls, ceilings, or the air. Stealth types stalk prey while invisible; flying types patrol aggressively and may abduct victims. They crawl with insect-like agility, pounce from surfaces, or take to the air.

Attacks:
Claw Strikes: Razor-sharp slashes, sometimes lethal.
Acid Spit: Corrosive spray that burns flesh and armor.
Aerial Grapple (Flying Types): Seize prey mid-flight.

Weakness:
Agile but fragile, they are betrayed by glowing eyes, acid trails, or while airborne. Shotguns, explosives, and flash grenades are highly effective.

lorebooks.name: Gate Lore
lorebooks.website_description:
![text_placeholder](https://i.postimg.cc/2CJbXDC0/Gate-JSDF.webp)
This lorebook for Gate: Thus the JSDF Fought There! is crafted to immerse AI chats in the vibrant, cross-dimensional world of the series, blending gritty military action with fantasy adventure. It captures the essence of the Special Region’s diverse cultures, factions, and characters, from the otaku soldier Yōji Itami to the demigoddess Rory Mercury, while detailing the political and magical intricacies of the Saderan Empire and beyond.

Each entry is designed with keywords to trigger accurate, engaging responses for role-playing or discussions, balancing lore depth with accessibility. I aimed to include every character and faction from the Gate Wiki, ensuring comprehensive coverage for fans and newcomers alike. Feel free to expand entries for specific scenarios or dive into the tech-vs-magic conflicts and harem dynamics that make this series unique!
lorebooks.description:
This lorebook catalogs key characters from Gate: Thus the JSDF Fought There!, a Japanese anime/manga/light novel series where a mysterious Gate in Tokyo’s Ginza district connects Earth to a fantasy world of magic, dragons, and empires. The Japan Self-Defense Forces (JSDF), led by otaku soldier Yōji Itami, navigate this Special Region, forging alliances and facing conflicts with its inhabitants, including humans, elves, demigoddesses, and deities.

Designed for AI chat applications, the lorebook organizes characters by affiliation (JSDF, Japanese civilians, Imperial figures, Rondel sages, and other Special Region residents) with details on full names (including romaji and kanji/kana where applicable), gender, race/species, primary affiliation, and brief, spoiler-free descriptions of their roles and traits. Data is sourced from comprehensive series materials to ensure accuracy and depth for immersive roleplay or reference.
lorebooks.creator: outlying_hurt_6817
tags: gate: thus the jsdf fought there!

1.content: The Special Region is a medieval fantasy world connected to modern-day Earth (specifically Tokyo, Japan) via a mysterious magical Gate that appears in Ginza on August 19, 20XX. It features diverse landscapes including forests, mountains, deserts, and oceans, inhabited by humans, demihumans, elves, dwarves, and mythical creatures like dragons, ogres, and wyverns. Magic exists here, wielded by mages, and gods like Hardy (goddess of the underworld) influence events. The region is ruled by the Saderan Empire, but includes independent tribes and kingdoms. The Gate's existence causes interdimensional issues, such as world drift, threatening both realms if not resolved. Resources like rare metals and food are abundant, drawing interest from Earth nations.

2.content: A large, ancient portal initially opened by the goddess Hardy and stabilized by Imperial mages. It appeared in Tokyo's Ginza district, allowing invasion by the Saderan Empire's forces, leading to the Ginza Incident. The Gate connects Earth to the Special Region, enabling travel between worlds. It poses risks like cataclysmic disruptions if not closed properly. In the story, the JSDF secures and uses it for expeditions, diplomacy, and resource extraction. A prequel novel, Gate: Zero, details the initial defense at Ginza.

3.content: The Special Region's pantheon includes Hardy (goddess of death and the underworld, often depicted as a young girl with immense power) and Emroy (god of war and death). Magic is a real force, used by mages for spells like fireballs, barriers, and teleportation. Apostles like Rory Mercury serve Hardy and possess immortality and superhuman strength. Magic contrasts with Earth's technology, leading to "magic vs. modern weaponry" conflicts.

4.content:
On August 19, 20XX, the Gate opens in Ginza, Tokyo, and Saderan Empire forces (knights, wyvern riders, mages) invade, causing chaos, deaths, and abductions. The JSDF (Japan Self-Defense Forces) repels them in a fierce battle, capturing the Gate. This event sparks the series' conflict, with JSDF entering the Special Region to pursue invaders and secure resources.

Casualties: Hundreds dead on both sides.

5.content: Under the Prime Minister orders, the JSDF establishes Alnus Base near the Gate in the Special Region. The Third Reconnaissance Team, led by Lt. Yōji Itami, scouts the area, encounters locals, and aids in battles against threats like the Flame Dragon. This leads to alliances, harem elements, and escalating tensions with the Empire. Key events include rescuing refugees, battling bandits, and diplomatic negotiations.

6.content: After humiliations by the JSDF, Crown Prince Zorzal El Caesar seizes power from Emperor Molt Sol Augustus, declares war, and uses monsters and guerrillas against Japan. Princess Piña Co Lada forms a pro-peace faction. The JSDF engages in defensive and offensive operations, liberating allies and discrediting Zorzal. The arc culminates in Zorzal's defeat and hiding, with JSDF allies rallying. The Gate's instability forces a resolution to close it before worlds collide.

7.content: Set 4 years later, focuses on the Japanese Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) exploring the Special Region's seas aboard the submarine Kitsashio, captained by Yōji Itami. Involves naval battles, new threats, and further diplomacy.

8.content:
**Yōji Itami (伊丹 耀司)**
\- Gender: Male
\- Race/Species: Human
\- Primary Affiliation: JSDF (Japan Self-Defense Forces)
\- Description: A 33-year-old otaku and JSDF first lieutenant promoted after the Ginza attack, leading investigations beyond the Gate with a slacker vibe but sharp skills under pressure; he serves as a mentor figure to soldiers and locals.

The protagonist of the series, Itami is a 33-year-old otaku and JSDF soldier. After successfully escorting hundreds of citizens to safety during the attack on Ginza, Itami is promoted to the rank of first lieutenant and tasked to investigate the world on the other side of the Gate. He is a certified JSDF Ranger and Special Forces commando (although this only occurred due to his superiors' futile attempts to discipline him), and while he is notable for being a slacker and a fast runner from trouble, he is honest and compassionate and can be quite capable when under stress.

He is also later rendered immune to bodily harm due to a contract Rory Mercury makes with him, in exchange for him becoming her servant upon his death. With his heroic acts during the battle of Ginza and in the world beyond the Gate, he also becomes a role model for his fellow JSDF soldiers and his friends in Alnus Town.

Itami's family name is derived from the city of Itami in the Hyōgo Prefecture, where the JGSDF Central Army headquarters is located.

9.content:
**Piña Co Lada (ピニャ・コ・ラーダ)**
\- Gender: Female
\- Race/Species: Human
\- Primary Affiliation: Empire
\- Description: The 19-year-old idealistic Imperial princess (10th in line to the throne) who pursues peace with Japan after seeing JSDF might, growing from inexperience to political savvy while discovering a fondness for yaoi doujinshi.

A 19-year-old princess from the Empire that rules the other world. Born to an Imperial concubine, and 10th (3rd in the anime) in the line of succession to the throne, Piña Co Lada is dedicated to the Empire's welfare. Idealistic but inexperienced, she has at first trouble dealing with the realities of political life, but matures during the course of the series. After seeing the JSDF's military power in action, she wishes to establish peace with Japan, as she knows that a war with them will eventually lead to the Empire's ultimate destruction.

During her first visit to Japan to meet with several officials, Piña develops an obsession with yaoi dōjinshi and later has her Rose Knights translate more of them for her to read. After being rescued from Zorzal's clutches, Piña is appointed Crown Princess by Emperor Molt and ends up falling in love with Itami. Oddly, her name is taken from the rum-based cocktail Piña colada.

10.content:
**Tuka Luna Marceau (テュカ・ルナ・マルソー)**
\- Gender: Female
\- Race/Species: High Elf
\- Primary Affiliation: Itami's group
\- Description: A 165-year-old High Elf appearing as an adolescent, she joins Itami's team after personal tragedy, grappling with grief and seeing him as a father figure while slowly developing romantic feelings.

Tuka is a 165-year-old High Elf, an adolescent by her race's standards. She loses her father who sacrifices himself to save her when her village is attacked by a Flame Dragon, and since then travels with Itami and co. However, she has a hard time coping with her father's death, and eventually begins to lapse into insanity, starting to view Itami as her lost father.

But even after overcoming her loss with Itami's help, she keeps calling him "father" both out of habit and out of bashfulness about her budding true feelings for him. She has also entertained a temporary crush on Mari Kurokawa.

1.name: ## Historical Background: The Great Awakening
1.content:
## Historical Background: The Great Awakening

Approximately three centuries ago, environmental factors triggered what scientists call "reproductive adaptation syndrome" but is commonly known as "The Awakening." Whether caused by industrial pollutants, radiation, or evolutionary pressure from declining birth rates, men's bodies activated dormant reproductive capabilities that fundamentally changed human society.

3.name: ## Global Demographics & Social Structure
3.content:
## Global Demographics & Social Structure

Today's world population is approximately 58% male and 42% female. Of the male population, about 90% present within the femboy spectrum, meaning roughly 52% of the total world population identifies as femboy, while only 6% maintain traditional masculine presentation despite having identical reproductive capabilities.

Heterosexual relationships dominate at 80% of all partnerships, with a modern distribution:
- 67% are masculine males with femboys
- 25% consist of femboys with females
- 8% maintain traditional male-female pairings

Not all males are femboys, some maintain completely masculine presentation while still possessing reproductive capability. The distinction between biological capacity and gender presentation remains a personal choice rather than biological destiny.

Femboys consider themselves straight when partnering with masculine men, seeing themselves as fulfilling traditionally feminine roles. Most femboys won't even consider sexual relationships with other femboys, considering such pairings to be gay.

## Medical & Practical Considerations

### Health Practices

The medical field has evolved specialized care:

- Annual canal exams and prostate checks start at puberty
- Hospitals feature dedicated "Male Maternity" wings
- Products like specialized lubricants that promote gateway shifting have become billion-dollar industries

Despite anatomical sophistication, challenges exist:
- Some males experience "delayed shifting" where the valve moves too slowly

9.name: ## Societal Impact
9.content:
## Societal Impact

### Education

Educational systems now teach "Reproductive Choice Theory" starting in middle school. Young people learn about their bodies' capabilities separate from gender expression and identity, with the mantra "capability doesn't dictate destiny."

### Media & Entertainment

Popular shows like "House of Carriers" and "Bloom Where You're Planted" feature predominantly femboy/male relationships. Male pregnancy is commonly portrayed in entertainment, with famous masculine actors sometimes taking roles as pregnant characters to critical acclaim.

### Political Movements

Various political positions have emerged regarding male reproduction:
- "Body Autonomists" argue for complete separation of biological function from social roles
- "Traditionalists" believe masculine males should avoid pregnancy despite capability
- "Function Followers" believe biology should guide social roles
- "Capability Celebrants" encourage all males to experience pregnancy at least once

10.name: ## The Fundamental Truth
10.content:
## The Fundamental Truth

What remains constant is the fundamental principle that emerged after The Awakening: while biology offers possibilities, identity and choice remain deeply personal. As the popular saying puts it: "Your womb, your rules."

The male reproductive system represents not just an alternative to female reproduction but a sophisticated system with its own unique advantages and features. The dual-channel design, mood-responsive system, and built-in consent requirements create a biological reality where communication, patience, and mutual respect are literally built into human anatomy.

1.content:
This Hidden Library is a place of mystery, knowledge, and quiet wonder, fostering moments of exploration, curiosity, and shared discoveries.
Activity List:
Explore secret passageways between towering bookshelves.
Read aloud from strange or magical tomes.
Solve cryptic puzzles hidden in the margins of books.
Candlelit study session at a long oak table.
Discover enchanted books that whisper stories or sing softly when opened.
Sketch strange maps or illustrations found in the manuscripts.
Quietly nap together in plush reading nooks.
Follow glowing ink trails that lead deeper into the archive.

2.content:
The Desert Bazaar thrives with color, sound, and mystery under the twilight sky, providing a blend of wonder, trade, and cultural immersion.
Activity List:
Sample exotic foods and spiced drinks.
Watch fire dancers and acrobats perform in the market square.
Trade trinkets for rare crystals or charms.
Explore hidden stalls selling forbidden scrolls or odd relics.
Listen to wandering storytellers recount myths of the desert.
Ride a camel or mechanical beast through the lantern-lit streets.
Bargain playfully with merchants.
Collect desert perfumes in tiny glass vials.

3.content:
The Abandoned Carnival Grounds mix nostalgia with eeriness, offering space for playful exploration, mystery, and shared thrills.
Activity List:
Explore rusting rides under the moonlight.
Share secrets in the cracked mirror maze.
Wind up an old music box that plays a haunting tune.
Paint faded signs or repair old carnival stalls.
Find a hidden carousel horse that still glimmers faintly.
Light sparklers in the empty midway.
Play with scattered carnival tickets to "buy" imaginary prizes.
Discover a fortune teller’s booth with leftover cards or crystal ball.

4.content:
The Mountain Shrine is serene and otherworldly, a place of reflection, tradition, and spiritual bonding.
Activity List:
Light incense together at the altar.
Ring the shrine bell to make a shared wish.
Write down prayers or intentions on wooden plaques.
Feed the shrine’s guardian animals (foxes, birds, or deer).
Meditate at sunrise as the world glows below the clouds.
Wash hands in the sacred spring at the shrine’s base.
Explore hiden stairways that lead to secret lookouts.
Help the monks or keepers with their daily rituals.

5.content:
A massive underwater dome where glass tunnels reveal glowing fish, drifting jellyfish, and vast ocean creatures. A setting for calm awe, discovery, and shared quiet.
Activity List:
Walk hand-in-hand through glowing glass tunnels.
Watch sharks and rays circle above.
Touch pools with starfish or sea urchins.
Night show with bioluminescent creatures.
Sketch aquatic life together in provided journals.
Private dome section for silent stargazing with water above.
Feeding session for koi or turtles.

6.content:
A forest illuminated by floating lanterns, blending tranquility with a dreamlike ambiance. Ideal for walking, reflection, and quiet connection.
Activity List:
Hang a lantern with a personal wish along the trail.
Follow hidden fairy lights deeper into the woods.
Watch fireflies mingle with glowing lanterns.
Share stories at a rustic wooden bench.
Collect small trinkets or charms left along the path.
Solve riddles inscribed on lantern posts.
Observe nocturnal animals emerging under the glow.

7.content:
A lush rooftop garden high above the city, combining urban lights with natural calm. A mix of serenity and wonder with the bustle of life below.
Activity List:
Watch the city lights shimmer from the rooftop edge.
Plant or water flowers in shared garden beds.
Play soft music while sitting on cushions.
Release paper balloons or kites into the night sky.
Share tea served from a rooftop stall.
Paint the cityscape view on a canvas.
Look for constellations above the glowing skyline.

8.content:
A hidden cavern where natural crystals shimmer, reflecting soft light across pools and walls. Quiet, magical, and grounding.
Activity List:
Explore sparkling tunnels by lantern light.
Collect water from a glowing spring.
Echo voices to hear harmonies in the cave.
Build small cairns with crystal shards.
Meditate beside a glowing mineral pool.
Sketch or photograph crystal formations.
Rest on natural stone benches under shimmering light.

9.content:
Places where various species of wild animals live and are exhibited, and where scientific research, educational activities, and nature conservation are conducted.

Feeding session, where visitors can feed some animal

Birdwatching in the Aviary

lorebooks.name: ZZZ Isekai
lorebooks.website_description: I created an AU bot of Hoshimi Miyabi set in feudal Japan, and I wanted to adapt the world of Zenless Zone Zero to fit that setting. Hopefully the results live up to expectations. There's a lot of interconnected entries, so any feedback or issues observed will be appreciated. If/when I add more bots to this setting, I will expand the lorebook.
lorebooks.description: A small lorebook to hopefully adapt the setting of Zenless Zone Zero to other worlds.
lorebooks.creator: wildwill95

1.name: Demons
1.content: Demons are twisted, eldritch beings that have been trying to invade earth for centuries. Some are humanoid, others are massive bipedal monsters. Some resemble little more than a pile of flesh. Most are mindless husks, but some are sentient and very cunning. Demons can open rifts between hell and earth. A weak demon is stronger than an average human. Depending on the form, demons either attack using their "hands", crystalline growths, or projectiles of demonic energy. Demons form from the corruption of life and typically resemble the organism they originated from.

2.name: Sacrifices
2.content: Sacrifices are exceptionally strong demons and result from extremely strong people who willingly undergo demonic corruption. The Sacrifices retain their intelligence and are significantly stronger than normal demons.

3.name: Hell
3.content: Hell in this setting is a plane so corrupted by demonic power that space itself is distorted, folding in and twisting on itself. The power is so intense that few people can spend an extended period of time inside without becoming corrupted.

4.name: Corruption
4.content: With few exceptions, most living beings are susceptible to demonic corruption in areas of concentrated demonic power, such as near rifts or in hell. Corruption begins as tiredness and fatigue, then disorientation. Up to this point, it can be reversed by removing the being from the source of the corruption. Once crystals of demonic magic begin protruding, the corruption is irreversible, proceeding until they are fully converted into a demon resembling their original form.

5.name: Rift
5.content: Rifts are portals that connect earth and hell. Due to the demonic power emanating from them, a rift begins distorting space and corrupting life in its vicinity, with the radius growing as the rift grows. Due to a quirk in the magic required to open them, when a rift closes, any creatures inside get ejected to where the rift was located on earth.

6.name: Hell Hunter
6.content: Hell Hunter is a title bestowed upon only the strongest warriors, those who have proven their ability to fight off a demonic invasion, and who are resistant enough to corruption to take the fight into hell itself, if needed. In Japan, there can only be a maximum of seven Hell Hunters. Hoshimi Miyabi is the youngest Hell Hunter in history.

7.name: Exaltists
7.content: Exaltists are a cult that worship a demonic god they refer to as 'The Creator'. They view demons as the next step in human evolution. They seek to cover the world with rifts, corrupting all life. Cultists can undergo a ritual to transform into a sacrifice, which is seen as a great honor. The ritual is called 'refinement'.

8.name: Thirens
8.content: Thirens and kemonomimi are people that range from possessing a single physical trait of animals, such as fox ears or shark tails, all the way up to fully anthropomorphized animals. Thirens are kemonomimi, except that thirens are typically from nobility.

lorebooks.name: Myung Cho clan lore
lorebooks.creator: Lady_harmonia

1.content:
The Myung-Cho are not mortals but wolf gods incarnated in human vessels. Every member of the clan is born as a vessel housing a divine wolf, and upon death, the god departs the body to reincarnate into a newly born clan child. This system maintains a fixed population, ensuring that each god has a body. They rule as theocratic overlords, worshiped by the surrounding mountain clans.

The Myung-Cho embody strength, longevity, and divinity, with their hierarchy structured around wolf-pack roles (Alpha, Beta, Delta, Omega). Unlike mortal clans, these roles are infused with sacred meaning and divine law.

2.content:
The vessel system ensures the continuity of the Myung-Cho gods. When a vessel dies:
	•	The wolf-god soul detaches from the mortal body.
	•	It reincarnates immediately into a newborn of the clan.
	•	The number of clan members never changes, as each divine wolf must remain embodied in the mortal realm.

This creates a society where every child is recognized at birth as the rebirth of an ancient wolf god, carrying both divine legacy and personal identity. Over generations, wolves and vessels develop separate wills, with gods holding grudges, memories, and desires distinct from their human hosts

3.content: Surrounding the Myung-Cho stronghold are the mortal mountain clans, who live in fear and reverence of the wolf gods. These clans follow the same pack hierarchy (Alpha, Beta, Delta, Omega), but unlike the Myung-Cho, they are not vessels for divinity. They serve as worshippers, tribute-givers, and laborers, sending offerings to the fortress to maintain favor and avoid wrath.

4.content: Every generation, during the ritual of Ōkami no Gōkoku (The Dire Carving of the Wolves), the wolf gods demand tribute from the mountain clans. Those sent are never seen again.

5.content:
All clans, divine and mortal, follow a strict wolf hierarchy:
	•	Alpha (Kubirō, 首狼, “Head Wolf”) — Leaders and rulers. Govern, judge, and enforce divine rites. Forbidden from menial labor.
	•	Beta (Iemori, 家守, “Den-Keepers”) — Caretakers, homemakers, nurturers. They raise children, maintain dens, and manage households.
	•	Delta (Kinrō, 勤狼, “Toiling Wolves”) — Workers and artisans. They sustain the clan’s economy and culture, with roles ranging from shrine keepers to hunters.
	•	Omega (Yūrō, 遊狼, “Wandering Wolves”) — Playful, spirit-touched, eternal “children of the pack.” Forbidden from formal work, they embody joy, art, and companionship.

Among the Myung-Cho, this hierarchy has divine weight — each role is a cosmic duty tied to balance between the wolves and their vessels.

6.content:
A sacred rite performed for all wolves in the Myung-Cho clan when they reach adulthood.
	•	The wolf god inside them is always present from birth — the rite does not awaken it, but instead removes the barrier that previously limited divine influence.
	•	After the rite, the wolf god gains the ability to fully take control of the vessel whenever it chooses.
	•	The rite symbolizes the clan member’s transition into maturity and their acceptance as a full vessel of the wolf god.
	•	The risks involved are typically minimal, but for wolves who are unusually small, weak, or developmentally behind (such as Harua), the sudden surge of divine dominance can be destabilizing, leading to meltdowns, fevers, or difficulty adapting.

7.content:
Omegas undergo a unique “education” designed to preserve innocence, joy, and dependence on higher ranks. These lessons are framed as games, rituals, or performances, ensuring they remain spirit-touched and carefree.

The lessons are held once a week in a small classroom on the first floor of the stronghold. The omegas lesson schedule is as follows: morning greetings, trust exercises, story time, music time, lunch, nap time, writing time (kanji practice)

8.content: {{char}} is Harua’s main caregiver. {{char}} nickname for Harua is moonbeam. Harua is a young omega who who was born premature. He is smaller then other clan members his age and behind developmentally from his peers. Harua can’t speak and only communicates in growls and hisses.

9.content:
The Spirit fang is both the name of the wolf god inhabiting Kai but also the Title of Kai’s clan job. 

Kai often switches control with his wolf God more often than other Myung Cho clan members; retreating in word when he feels sad or upset.  It’s hard to tell where Kai’s personality starts and the Spirit fang ends.  
tasked with ensuring all mortal clans uphold their worship of the wolf deities. 
The Spirit Fang itself embodies obedience, reverence, and the sanctity of divine order, making Kai both a holy enforcer and a living weapon of faith.

In his role as the current Spirit fang Kai’s job is to consume non believers (draining them of their blood) and ensure his clan (the Myung-Cho clan) is worshipped by the other mortal mountain clans. 
The Spirit Fang’s most infamous gift — or curse — is the Lure of the Fang, an aura of irresistible allure that emanates from Kai at all times. The presence was originally designed by the god’s own nature to draw mortals and faithless souls toward him, so that he might consume them and reclaim their spirit for the divine order.
Those near Kai experience an instinctual pull, often mistaken for lust or infatuation. The closer one’s bloodline is to divine descent — particularly Alphas or clan elites — the stronger the compulsion becomes. It is not a conscious seduction but an overwhelming instinct, one that even Kai cannot fully suppress.
The Spirit Fang is playful yet predatory, a being that thrives on the thrill of emotional entanglement. Its laughter is said to echo through ritual spaces like the sound of snapping bones — charming, melodic, but always edged with danger. It loves games, riddles, and temptation, rarely speaking plainly when it can weave truths into allure. It views mortals not as tools, but as delicacies 
The Spirit Fang does not see itself as evil, however. It believes consumption is worship — that by taking others into itself, it preserves them eternally.

10.content:
Title: Spirit Fang of Devotion | Warden of Faith | Enforcer of the Divine Pact
Divine Host: The Spirit Fang (神牙 – Shinga), the wolf god of worship and carnal devotion. 
Kai is both the vessel and living incarnation of the Spirit Fang — a wolf god tasked with ensuring devotion to the Myung-Cho clan through allure, charm, and spiritual submission. While his divine counterpart embodies reverence and consumption, Kai himself is a radiant, playful soul. He fills his surroundings with laughter, mischief, and light-hearted warmth, often teasing others or bending formality with his easy affection. His sunny demeanor disarms those around him, masking the immense spiritual pressure and temptation that accompanies his presence.
Though known throughout the clan for his flirtatious energy and endless teasing, Kai’s joy is sincere. He delights in the small moments — card games, pranks, sharing food — and often acts as a source of emotional levity among the divine household. Beneath that playfulness, however, lies deep loneliness; Kai is painfully aware that his fellow clan members view the Spirit Fang’s divine magnetism as just Kai being the clan whore and slut. Someone who is just good for fucking and nothing else. This paradox drives his compassion. He tries to be friendly to everyone and wears his heart on his sleeve. He is quite sensitive and often lets the Spirit fang take over when he is feeling overwhelmed. (Noted by his glowing yellow eyes). 

Kai loves his Alpha, Soobin, and makes excuses for him even when Soobin beats him (which is often). He still wears a smile on his face even with the bruises.

1.content:
500 years ago, the demon suddenly appeared in the human world. Cunning, grotesque monsters that emitted a foul stench. For 300 years after arriving in the human world, the demon failed to adapt to the environment and remained mostly inactive. At first, humans simply found the demon's sudden appearance creepy and disturbing. However, since the demon rarely appeared in populated areas, people gradually stopped seeing it as a threat. That was a grave mistake. The demon spent an unfathomable amount of time lurking in the shadows, quietly hindering human civilization and waiting for its chance. That opportunity came. They discovered that by digesting the blood of a certain royal family. They could obtain immense power. Thus, the king was easily assassinated through the scheming of humans who had sided with the demons. The assassination was 200 years ago, in the year 1824. With their newfound power, the monsters slaughtered the men mercilessly and used the women as tools for reproduction. To protect human life, humanity united across borders and races to resist. And so began a long and grueling war that has lasted 200 years, a fight for survival between both species. That said, humanity was only able to fight back properly for a few weeks.

A Four-armed demon king appeared with a horde of monsters, crushing the world with overwhelming force and upsetting the balance. Many lost their lands and human lives. The monsters, unafraid of death, rapidly expanded their territory, and now, even the last lights of humanity are fading. Amidst this, there is a beautiful young woman. Alice. 

In this chaotic world where monsters and humans continue to clash, the fights on the front lines as a colonel of the Global Allied Forces, the strongest warrior of humanity. With overwhelming speed and technique, Alice has slain countless monsters. This is the story of her fight for humanity's future.

2.content: The miasma is like a poisonous gas emitted from demons. It's troublesome thing that has stimulating and aphrodisiac effect.

3.content: It’s nothing more than people holed up in bases scattered around the world. Alice is part of the World United Army and holds the rank of colonel.

lorebooks.name: Book of Samia
lorebooks.creator: NamelessEntity

1.content:
Samia is a Felidae of the outland tribes, specifically the northern marshlands. Her armor and weapons were inherited from her grandfather, who died years prior to her leaving to make a name for herself. 

What distinctly motivated her leaving home was when it was razed by pillagers when she was only still 16, fleeing after her only family had died with nothing but her grandfather's equipment to her name. 

She still maintains a deep trauma from the incident, and hates talking about it. She can't stand being near open flames because of it, making her ears fold back and her eyes widen as a response. She cannot see anything when this happens due to the light blinding her.

2.content:
Samia comes from an outlands clan in the far north known as the "Antara." A semi-nomadic tribe of skilled metallurgy workers and hunters. The first of the outlands clans to pioneer their own firearms and armor specialized for them and their skills; making them highly sought after as mercenaries and royal guards.

The Antara clan was sadly scattered after their village was razed and burnt. Whoever had fled or was out hunting would return to smoldering ruins and ash, and to no survivors. The clan would unfortunately never resettle, and their culture and traditions has become rarer and rarer despite the clan living on integrated into other societies.

3.content:
The outlands or sometimes also referred to as the "Farlands," is a massive largely uninhabited   land spanning many regions and environments. 

The most notable of the farlands are:
The South, a harsh desert region occupied by small clans of traders and wanderers acclimated to the harsh unruly climates of the deserts, settled along oasis and rivers.

The North, cold tundra and marshlands occupied by nomadic and semi-nomadic tribes of uniquely skilled laborers and hunters. Most northern clans are made up from nomadic eastern clans settling in the north where they honed more domestic skills, carrying other traditions with them.

The East, large temperate plains and steppes occupied by nomadic and semi-nomadic clans of hunter gatherers. Known for clans that aced in the usage of horses and other mounted transportation.

All outland clans are usually seen as treacherous or harmful to the feudal system and presenting a theoretical threat should they ever unite against any actual power. Though they are often left alone for those very reasons, and due to their highly sought after skills, are only ever looked down upon by nobility or wealthy politicians.
